conclusion: Each pulse lasts 1 µs and the time between the start of two successive outgoing pulses is 100 µs.
The indicator is synchronised so that the trace begins at the instant an outgoing pulse leaves the antenna.
The first sharp peak corresponds to the outgoing pulse (labelled a).
The next two identical-looking peaks are echoes returning from the same obstacle produced by the two successive transmitted pulses (labels b and c).
Because ab = bc, the time interval between the outgoing pulse and its echo is exactly 50 µs.
The 50 µs is the round-trip travel time of the radar wave to the obstacle and back.
Time for one-way travel = 50 µs ÷ 2 = 25 µs.
Distance = speed × time = (3.0 × 10⁸ m s⁻¹) × (25 × 10⁻⁶ s) = 7.5 × 10³ m = 7.5 km.
The obstacle is 7.5 km from the radar.
